headline: Pelosi softens opposition to stock trading ban for members of Congress
author: Don Jacobson
sentences: Although appearing to shift that stance Wednesday, Pelosi also said she wanted to see stricter enforcement of the existing Stock Act -- which requires lawmakers to report any stock trades they make within a certain time period -- and suggested that any ban be instituted "government-wide."
Pelosi said during her weekly Capitol Hill press conference the House Administration Committee is working "to review the options that members are putting forth" on a potential stock trading ban.
Pelosi, however, initially refused to give her backing to the idea that lawmakers be banned from trading individual stocks, telling reporters in December, "We're a free-market economy.
Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Softening her previous opposition, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Wednesday Democrats are now working on legislation to ban members of Congress from trading stocks.
"We'll go forward with what the consensus is," she told reporters, adding that she has submitted her own criteria and thought a measure could be crafted "pretty soon."
Shortly afterwards, 27 House members urged in a letter to Pelosi and Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy that they bring proper legislation forward.
The letter, drafted by Rep. Jared Golden, D-Maine, claims that members of Congress are meant to serve the country, not "turn a quick buck."
Mark Kelly of Arizona and Jon Ossoff of Georgia introduced a bill prohibiting lawmakers from trading stocks while in office.
